qas.question: Who was the first person to sequence a viral genome?
Which viral genome did Fiers sequence?
Who was first to sequence a DNA-based genome?
What organization first sequenced a bacterial genome?
In what year was the archaeon genome sequenced?
In what year did Fred Sanger first establish the complete nucleotide sequence of  a viral RNA genome?
When was The Institute for Genome Research founded?

plausible_answers.text: The first genome sequence for an archaeon

qas.question: What did Walter Fiers complete in 1996?

plausible_answers.text: The first bacterial genome to be sequenced

qas.question: What did Fred Sanger complete when part of a team in 1995?
What was the name of the first bacterial genome sequenced by Fred Sanger in 1995?

context: In <b5_0>1976<b5_0/>, <a0_0>Walter Fiers<a0_0/> at the University of Ghent (Belgium) was the first to establish the complete nucleotide sequence of a viral RNA-genome (<a1_0>Bacteriophage MS2<a1_0/>). The next year <a2_0>Fred Sanger<a2_0/> completed the first DNA-genome sequence: Phage Φ-X174, of 5386 base pairs. The first complete genome sequences among all three domains of life were released within a short period during the mid-1990s: <b8_0>The first bacterial genome to be sequenced<b8_0/> was that of <b9_0>Haemophilus influenzae<b9_0/>, completed by a team at The <a3_0>Institute for Genomic Research<a3_0/> in 1995. A few months later, the first eukaryotic genome was completed, with sequences of the 16 chromosomes of budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae published as the result of a European-led effort begun in the mid-1980s. <b7_0>The first genome sequence for an archaeon<b7_0/>, Methanococcus jannaschii, was completed in <a4_0><b6_0>1996<b6_0/><a4_0/>, again by The Institute for Genomic Research.
